body:
Both the issues you refer to are clearly marked as fixed for the 3.8 release, so you won't see any sign of the changes when running 3.7.1. You can, if you like, download later dev versions of the framework from our myget feed.

`ParallelScope.Fixtures` indicates that any fixtures below that point in the tree should be run in parallel. It's not valid on methods because methods don't contain fixtures.

If you want some tests in a fixture to be run in parallel (with one another) those fixtures should be marked as Parallelizable (ParallelScope.Self or omitted). 

In general, you should avoid those settings marked as non-browsable even though some versions of VS show them in error in the Intellisense. Use NonParallelizable rather than ParallelScope.None.

I'll assume that you have no higher-level `ParallelizableAttribute` either on the assembly or a `SetUpFixture`.

The `[Parallelizable]` on the fixture class will cause it to run in parallel with any other fixtures that have the same attribute. Since it's parameterized, the two instances will run in parallel with one another.

The `[NonParallelizable]` and `[Parallelizable]` attributes on test 1 are in conflict with one another. The test should be marked as non-runnable. Since it isn't, that may be a bug - see below. My guess is that one of the two attributes is taking precedence over the other.

Similarly, the `[Parallelizable(ParallelScope.Fixtures)]` attribute should cause test 2 to be invalid. Again, that may be a bug. In this case, the attribute will have no effect at all, since there are no fixtures "included" in the test method.

I see you are running an older copy of the console runner. Is it possible you are also running an older copy of the framework? The code that checks for invalid combinations is fairly recent.

As for what you want to achieve with multiple fixtures... here's a diagram of what I understand.

```C#
[TestFixture("data"), Parallelizable]
public class A
{
    [NonParallelizable]
    public void aa()

   ...
}

[TestFixture("data"), Parallelizable]
public class B
{
   ...
}
```

If `data` provides three sets of arguments, we will have six fixture instances running potentially in parallel. I'll assume that all the methods, except for `aa` have `[Parallelizable]` (You could alternatively use `ParallelScope.Self | ParallelScope.Children` on the fixtures, with the same result)

Assuming we are running with at least six cores and we start in parallel mode, all six fixtures would be initialized in parallel (created and one time setup run). In addition, all the methods except for `aa` would continue to run in parallel. Onetime teardown for the instances of fixture B would also complete.

Eventually, there would be no more tests able to run in parallel. The dispatcher would then switch to its non-parallel mode (we call it a change of shift) and run `aa`. It would continue to run any other non-parallel tests until there were no more to run. Then it would switch back to parallel mode to run the teardowns for fixture A.

There is no interference among these tests unless you have coded them to somehow interfere with one another. If that's the case, then they can't be run in parallel at all.

I hope this explains things a bit better.

As I have said previously, I am the most recent version of the framework, v3.8.0-dev-04267. I have been testing by both running the tests in Visual Studio, as well as using the 3.6.1 console runner to ensure it is not one or the other causing the problem.

I also just tested a slightly different setup using the 3.8 dev,
```
    [TestFixture]
    [TestFixtureSource(nameof(Params))]
    [NonParallelizable]
    public class UnitTest2
    {
        private static object[] Params = {
            new object[] { "test 1" },
            new object[] { "test 2" }
        };
        public UnitTest2(string test)
        {
        }

        [Test]
        [Parallelizable(ParallelScope.Self)]
        public void NUnitTest1() {...}

        [Test]
        [Parallelizable(ParallelScope.Fixtures)]
        public void NUnitTest2(){ ... }
    }
```
this setup seems to be intermittently failing as well. Sometimes it will fully pass, sometimes it will only run 3 out of 4 tests. Sometimes it will hang and throw the following error:
```
 System.NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object.
   at NUnit.Framework.Internal.Execution.WorkItemQueue.get_IsEmpty()
   at NUnit.Framework.Internal.Execution.WorkShift.get_HasWork()
   at NUnit.Framework.Internal.Execution.ParallelWorkItemDispatcher.StartNextShift()
   at NUnit.Framework.Internal.Execution.ParallelWorkItemDispatcher.OnEndOfShift(Object sender, EventArgs ea)
   at NUnit.Framework.Internal.Execution.WorkShift.EndShift()
   at NUnit.Framework.Internal.Execution.WorkShift.<StartWorkers>b__26_1(TestWorker s, WorkItem ea)
   at NUnit.Framework.Internal.Execution.TestWorker.TestWorkerThreadProc()
   at System.Threading.ThreadHelper.ThreadStart_Context(Object state)
   at System.Threading.ExecutionContext.RunInternal(ExecutionContext executionContext, ContextCallback callback, Object state, Boolean preserveSyncCtx)
   at System.Threading.ExecutionContext.Run(ExecutionContext executionContext, ContextCallback callback, Object state, Boolean preserveSyncCtx)
   at System.Threading.ExecutionContext.Run(ExecutionContext executionContext, ContextCallback callback, Object state)
   at System.Threading.ThreadHelper.ThreadStart()
   at NUnit.Framework.Internal.Execution.WorkItemQueue.get_IsEmpty()
   at NUnit.Framework.Internal.Execution.WorkShift.get_HasWork()
   at NUnit.Framework.Internal.Execution.ParallelWorkItemDispatcher.StartNextShift()
   at NUnit.Framework.Internal.Execution.ParallelWorkItemDispatcher.OnEndOfShift(Object sender, EventArgs ea)
   at NUnit.Framework.Internal.Execution.WorkShift.EndShift()
   at NUnit.Framework.Internal.Execution.WorkShift.<StartWorkers>b__26_1(TestWorker s, WorkItem ea)
   at NUnit.Framework.Internal.Execution.TestWorker.TestWorkerThreadProc()
   at System.Threading.ThreadHelper.ThreadStart_Context(Object state)
   at System.Threading.ExecutionContext.RunInternal(ExecutionContext executionContext, ContextCallback callback, Object state, Boolean preserveSyncCtx)
   at System.Threading.ExecutionContext.Run(ExecutionContext executionContext, ContextCallback callback, Object state, Boolean preserveSyncCtx)
   at System.Threading.ExecutionContext.Run(ExecutionContext executionContext, ContextCallback callback, Object state)
   at System.Threading.ThreadHelper.ThreadStart()
```
As for the multiple fixtures, All of what you said is fine, except it is essential `aa` is not  `NonParallelizable`. `aa` is the longest test out of the entire suite of tests, so forcing it to be `NonParallelizable` would increase the duration of the test run significantly. I don't want to create another separate test fixture, `C`,  for `aa` as then I am duplicating a significant amount of code from `A`. I'd rather not create a base fixture that both `C` and `A` derive from to solve this problem, as that would make this significantly different from what has already been implemented elsewhere in the current structure.

If the errors only occur when running with attributes that should be forbidden, then I suggest you stop doing that! We will eventually fix the error and the invalid combos will be flagged as non-runnable anyway.

What I haven't yet understood is exactly what you are hoping to have happen as a result of using `ParallelScope.Fixtures` on a method. If I understood that, I could perhaps give you an alternative.

WRT method `aa`, is it the case that you want it to run in parallel, but just not in parallel with certain other tests? For example, not with the other tests in the same fixture?

If so, that's the unimplemented feature we describe in #165. Until it's implemented, I'm afraid that parallelism is basically all or nothing for each method.

Based on your sample code, I'm re-opening this so we can confirm it and figure out why the tests are not being invalidated.

Haha, I know they are wrong, I was more so just curious what would happen. 

WRT method `aa`,
I don't want the different fixture instances of the test `aa` to run in parallel. However, I would like to have the individual instances of the test `aa` run in parallel with different tests within the fixture, as well as in parallel with other fixtures. I hope that makes sense.

issue.title: Initial tests of parallel execution, shift changing, etc.
issue.body:
This PR is intended to collect fixes for a number of parallelism issues, particularly around use of SetUpFixtures but also with the handling of parallel and non-parallel TestFixtures and the smooth changing of shifts within the dispatcher.

The initial commit sets up some infrastructure and adds a few unit tests of the parallel dispatcher. Those tests are known to fail intermittently, just as user runs are failing intermittently in some cases.

The issues I hope to address in this PR include #1239, ~~#1905~~, #2364, #2388, #2467 and #2471. I'll add "Fixes" notations when I think any of them is fixed.

I'd like it if @nunit/framework-team members followed along and commented.

Fixes #1239 (needs review)
Fixes #2364
Fixes #2395
Fixes #2467
Fixes #2471
Fixes #2478

body:
This will be fixed by PR #2476. The error was not being recognized correctly.

Note, however, that the example given was not that of a `TestMethod` but of a `ParameterizedMethodSuite`. The intention is that `ParallelScope.Children` should work on a parameterized test method, which has children. I added tests to prove this in the PR.
